item.title: Famitsu Review Scores: Issue 1897
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2025/05/famitsu-review-scores-issue-1897

  • PS4
  • PS5
  • Switch
  • Xbox One
  • Xbox Series

Yasha: Legends of the Demon Blade and more scored.

This week’s Famitsu review scores are in.

  • Frog Detective: The Entire Mystery (Switch) – 7/7/8/9 [31/40]
  • The Garden of Hermeneus (PS5, PS4, Switch) – 7/8/8/7 [30/40]
  • Two Point Museum (PS5, Xbox Series) – 9/8/8/8 [33/40]
  • Yasha: Legends of the Demon Blade (PS5, Xbox Series, PS4, Xbox One, Switch) – 8/8/7/7 [30/40]

Thanks, Ryokutya2089.

item.title: Tsukuyomi: The Divine Hunter now available
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2025/05/tsukuyomi-the-divine-hunter-now-available

  • PC
  • Smartphone

Card creation roguelike from former ATLUS illustrator Kazuma Kaneko.

Tsukuyomi: The Divine Hunter, the free-to-play “card creation roguelike” game by former ATLUS illustrator Kazuma Kaneko, is now available for PC via Steam, iOS via App Store, and Android via Google Play with cross-save, COLOPL announced. It supports English, Japanese, Traditional Chinese, and Simplified Chinese language options.

Here is an overview of the game, via its store pages:

About

A new world from visionary creator Kazuma Kaneko. This roguelike card game is the latest work by the legendary creator, known for countless masterpieces.

Story

In Tokyo’s bayside area stands “THE HASHIRA,” a state-of-the-art, ultra-high-rise complex. The tower has become a sealed-off space crawling with monstrous beings.

To eliminate the target lurking at the very top, Tsukuyomi, an elite organization sworn to protect the nation, begins its mission—.

Key Features

  • Deckbuilding Roguelike – In this dungeon-exploration game, players use a variety of cards with different abilities to battle enemies and make their way forward. Each run is unique—the types of cards you acquire and the structure of the dungeon change every time you play. Lose a battle, and everything you’ve gained during that run will be lost.
  • Battle System – Combat unfolds as a turn-based card battle. Players draw cards at random from their deck and must adapt their strategy to the current situation. Each turn, you can take a single action: attack or defend using a card from your hand.
  • Dungeon Exploration – While exploring, you’ll encounter branching paths and various events that require you to make key decisions. Each choice you make may significantly affect the outcome of your journey…
  • Supported Languages – Japanese, English, Traditional Chinese, and Simplified Chinese (planned).
